I left my stable job in the public sector 8 months ago and started seeking a post-graduate degree in analytics this fall, just wanna share that I felt resonated when you mentioned logging out of those distractions like Netflix and prime video, and I know how hard it is to make yourself away from them.  Thanks for helping me to make a resolute decision on getting rid of streaming media and making time for truly important tasks.

author: @domino_2396
text: Onion, and Mr Alex Bond, I just started with my data analyst career, your content and your tutorials help me a lot. I discovered partial over in your tutorials, and it's one of the functions I recently used in my new job that I truly feel like I'm an analyst now. (I'm self taught so I know a lot in your advanced sql, then know only a few in the intermediate ones)   your content helped me prepare me on what I should expect on this field, and frankly, I wish I found this channel while I was looking for jobs, but for a career shift, my current company is already good.   A friend asked me to be a guest speaker for their young professionals forum to teach stuff about excel. I'd probably go through your videos for pointers. I'm also eagerly waiting for your power bi and python videos. thank you for the content. Glad to be part of the 300, or 30

text: I’m currently in a job that pays pretty well ($85k) but I’m stretched wayyyyy too thin and I’m expected to be the master of all trades (yes, master). A sliver of my job requires me to pull data from our CRM, create dashboards and identify trends, percentages, have relationships with our tech vendors, etc.  Then one day a tech vendor told me I would be a good data analyst. I have yet to start training or a course but everything I watch and read gives me the impression that it would fit my skill set.  Going to do some LinkedInLearning courses to get started.

There is no freedom in wanting more everytime you reach the next goal.

author: @wilsonman8661
text: I felt compelled to pause the video to agree wholeheartedly with what you were talking about around the 9:00 mark, Alex. Making positive changes isn't about cutting things out; you have to actually replace that time with valuable efforts. If you don't intentionally fill that newfound gap in your schedule, you will inevitably fall back to old habits. You can't just quit old habits; you have to create new ones to take their place. (It's very similar with retirement too, where you need something to run to, not just work to run from... but I digress.) I don't know if you have followed any of Cal Newport's work but he talks about this a lot.  (Onions. 😂 Also, it's very annoying but my math is frequently off by a factor of 10 when I just throw numbers out there so kudos. -_-)

Saying that, the test isn't 100% but a good starting point if someone wants to gain self awareness.
